subject: designs: Host collecting thermal zone config information from BMC

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.
Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.

Patch Set 2:

Please add topic "design"

Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Maybe I'm missing something, but isn't a lot of this already solved by the bmcweb oem redfish fan interface?  Yes, that interface isn't available over IPMI today, but that seems like a much easier problem to solve than trying to solve the issue of defining the whole feature at a top level.  I think all of your use cases are already comprehended, even if 

I think it would be really good if we could avoid duplication between these two interfaces.  Btw, the schemas linked below aren't set in stone;  If we need modifications to enable new use cases, or things that we missed when we implemented this the first time, I'm happy to see mods made.

I will continue to do a better review next week.

Schema definition:
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/f5e906baa91fda7125916451b9366122fb2877bf/static/redfish/v1/schema/OemManager_v1.xml#L47

A response from my system is attached below.  All of this interface is modifiable by normal REST types.
{
    "@odata.context": "/redfish/v1/$metadata#Manager.Manager",
    "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc",
    "@odata.type": "#Manager.v1_3_0.Manager",
    "Actions": {
        "#Manager.Reset": {

Ed, just to clarify --> can we query this information over dbus without redfish or bmcweb running -- as enabling web features on bmc right now is a bit of an issue (not even related strictly speaking to there not being a direct link, there are lots of security issues that would need to be addressed).

Patch Set 2:

(14 comments)

I'm not advocating for everyone using redfish, or you guys even using bmcweb at all.  What I do want to is for OpenBMC to share an object model for this between the interfaces, and I think between entity-manager and redfish/bmcweb we've worked through a lot of the "need to read platform thermal configuration" problems, although we've been a bit slow in the documentation department as of late.

Also, because you mentioned the S word, what do you guys think about security on this kind of thing?  Given that it makes it pretty easy to shut down all fan control by simply writing a null fan configuration, do we need some kind of sane defaults or limitations on what this interface is allowed to set?

For the X86 platforms that this is targeting, is PECI hooked up?

PS, that's for posting this.
Topic set to design

Patch Set 2:

> Please add topic "design"

Done. But where was this an agreed-upon requirement?

Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
>

> > (1 comment)
> > 
> > Maybe I'm missing something, but isn't a lot of this already solved by the bmcweb oem redfish fan interface?  Yes, that interface isn't available over IPMI today, but that seems like a much easier problem to solve than trying to solve the issue of defining the whole feature at a top level. > Ed, just to clarify --> can we query this information over dbus without redfish or bmcweb running -- as enabling web features on bmc right now is a bit of an issue (not even related strictly speaking to there not being a direct link, there are lots of security issues that would need to be addressed).

I missed that this was a question.  Yes, all of the information in that schema is pulled from the sensor daemons and entity-manager through DBus.  Redfish (for the most part) doesn’t have any persistent data for exactly this reason.

Please ignore my flagrant typos.  I need to get a spelling and grammar checker into Gerrit.

Thanks for pushing this design.

This all looks reasonable to me as it will fit well with what we use internally. I'm curious also about Ed's take since he had a lot to say before... but I also wonder whether we should strictly define the scope of this particular design doc to avoid scope creep.

Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(5 comments)

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> This all looks reasonable to me as it will fit well with what we use internally. I'm curious also about Ed's take since he had a lot to say before... but I also wonder whether we should strictly define the scope of this particular design doc to avoid scope creep.

Too many reviews means I haven't been able to get back to this for a while.  I'm going to post my incomplete comments made a while back, and make the statement that I think we're all in agreement in principal, just details need working out, but I don't think that should hold up this design.

One thing I realized far too late about this review:  It's largely about transferring thermal zone information to the host _to allow in-band operating system thermal management_.  Most of the architectures I support require complete out-of-band thermal solutions, as I generally don't control the software that's run on the host, and therefore generally can't trust it to make thermal adjustments that could damage the system overall.  This is why we (Intel) tend to push things like PECI, ipmb, and MCTP to enable more devices with thermal monitoring.

There's a lot of overlap with other things being worked on (like entity-manager), and I'm happy to continue to provide input, but I suspect once completed, I likely won't make use of this design simply because it relies on an operating system component that the BMC has no control over.

Using something dynamic like entity manager?  Or are you thinking a more fixed sensor list?
I will try to use entity manager

Doesn't this cause really strange behavior in PID loops?  If the sensor with the least available margin changes, doesn't that invalidate the derivative and integral coefficients of the PID controller?
Does it make more sense to, in this case, run an identical control loop on the main processor (in band), and have the control loop "request" pwm outputs of the BMC?  The BMC would then set the fans to the maximum of<bmc requested pwm> and <host requested pwm>.

Would this fast-changing sensor mechanism be used for anything more than main system processor or dimm temperature?  In a perfect world, it seems like it would be easier to just poll the CPU DTS margin directly from PECI (for Intel CPUs).  I'm not an expert on OpenPower CPUs, but I think they have a similar out of band mechanism.
The PID control loop on the BMC only requires the fleeting margin sensor value. The rest is automatically taken care internally inside the PID loop control.
Not really following this.  Are you advocating for a fixed sensor number of 0XD0 for all platforms?  What does the below data structure represent?  What's transferred between the BMC and the host?

The below data structure in the host side says : There is a zone called central and the fleeting margin sensor Id for that zone is 208. (this is a exisiting datastructure on the host side and this doc's aim is to remove this).

Not true.....  Peci is supported at a hardware level, as well as has a dbus daemon that supports intel processors today:

https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/master/src/CPUSensor.cpp
/s/hardware/driver/g/
Thanks for pointing this out.
ok
This paragraph feels very redundant to the requirements section.  Could they be collapsed?  Does the requirements section need to be amended a bit?
Done

the definition of the entity instance field is very subjective, and very few companies actually agree on that the definition is, given the number of corner cases.  We can try to walk through and define exactly what entity instance should be used for, and how to handle it in complicated cases (like 3 hot swap backplanes, each with 3 drives for example)
Or... I would recommend just not using the instance field at all, and just rely on the fact that SDR records are unique.
Would like to define exactly what entity instance should be used for.
I guess I'm advocating that given the fuzzy definition, it shouldn't be used, and we should use something more concrete instead, with a different name to disambiguate it from IPMI.

Would prefer to not put fixed definitions in a single file, given that system configurations will change, even at runtime, as hardware is installed and removed.  While we could have the superset, it's unlikely we'll catch it all.
Entity-manager is an attempt to try to define this kind of stuff at a component level, and expose it to dbus.  I would really like to see us use that (or something similar to that) rather than a flat file.
I will try to use Entity Manager

if this is the way you want to go, a more complicated example would be good.   How are add in cards defined?  What about components with multiple sensors?  What about components detected at runtime.

Per my comment above, I'd like to do away with the flat file, and use something more dynamic;  However, I'm open to what that could be.
Info is needed only for DIMMs, CPUs, PCI slots.

I'm not really understanding your statement.  I have platforms that have thermal control for hot swap backplanes, OCP modules, SAS modules, and all manner of other replaceable components.

With that said, I think they fall within a range, so if you could provide a concrete example of a PCIe add in card, I suspect I can infer from that what other things I would need to do to adapt this to other components.

The reason we use the silkscreen names for the PCIe connectors is so that we can be agnostic to the various plugin cards which could be attached there on our platforms. The intent is essentially to say "there may be something plugged into this PCIe slot which the host must monitor on behalf of the BMC".

Some possible examples could be a network card or SSD where thermal sensors are read by the host and cannot be read by a BMC (on our specific platform).

For your platforms with hot swap backplanes, OCP modules, SAS modules, etc., are these all components which must be monitored by the host? If so, is it possible for them to have a silkscreen name?
Friendly ping
After having read this commands description, I'm not really following what it's for.  isn't all of this information (entity ID, and name) in the Type 1 SDR sensor records?
I needed the silk screen name for the device associated with the Entity ID and Entity Instance.  I did not find this info in the Type 1 SDR sensor records.
Isn't that just the "name" field?
Is this proposal being proposed for OpenBMC standardization, or as a google specific thing?
For OpenBMC standardization.
might want to remove the part about "google Oem" then
Json would be preferred, but not sure if you guys want to tackle that.
Done

If all entities are returned in a single command, aren't we going to hit IPMI payload limits pretty quickly as the entity list gets larger?  (I haven't done the math, so feel free to call me on it if you think I'm wrong) For the systems I'm on, my gut says that they would overflow the ipmi payload limit of ipmitool (which is artificially low in most distributed versions and was only fixed recently).  Most other IPMI frameworks have similar limitations.
Only one entity name is returned per single command
AH, I read your diagram wrong.  I thought N was enumerating over names.

Maybe I'm really overthinking it, but is there anything in the above payloads that the host system doesn't already have?  I would hope the host knows PCIe card counts, Processor core counts, and dimm counts without needing to ask the BMC.  Is the goal here for the host to map the in-band sensors to ipmi automatically?
How would a host differentiate between a system where the BMC has direct access to DIMM temps or PECI, and a system where the BMC needed those values provided by in-band.

The goal here is for host to fetch two pieces of information from BMC : 
1) what are the different zones and what are the devices in each zone
2) what is the fleeting margin sensor Id for a zone

For system with PECI there will be no temperature sensor which is settable.(step 1 in the algorithm)

For next time, Limit the subject line to 50 characters

From https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/


The seven rules of a great Git commit message
    Separate subject from body with a blank line
    Limit the subject line to 50 characters
    Capitalize the subject line
    Do not end the subject line with a period
    Use the imperative mood in the subject line
    Wrap the body at 72 characters
    Use the body to explain what and why vs. how
